speedread.para: Value added tax (VAT) is an EU tax levied by Customs & Excise on supplies for a consideration made by a taxable person in the UK in the course or furtherance of a business.

Taxable person. A taxable person is an individual, limited company or other entity which is registered, or required to be registered for VAT. The threshold for compulsory registration is a historical annual turnover of £50,000. However, a taxpayer may choose to register voluntarily.

Input and output tax. VAT is borne economically by the ultimate consumer of the goods or services supplied but is the liability of the person making the supply. Suppliers generally deduct an amount equal to the VAT on the supplies to them (input tax) from the VAT which they charge on onward supplies (output tax) and pay the difference to Customs. At each stage of the supply chain the net VAT paid is on the value added at that stage.

Categories. Supplies are divided into three main categories: standard rated supplies, zero rated supplies and exempt supplies. Most supplies are standard rated and therefore subject to VAT at the standard rate of 17.5%. Zero rated supplies do not require the supplier to charge VAT. They comprise a number of socially beneficial items such as new houses, however, unlike an exempt supply a zero rated supply is a taxable supply chargeable at a zero rate. Suppliers are not required to account for output tax on exempt supplies but are unable to recover the input tax on those supplies which they receive that are attributable to the exempt supplies. Exempt supplies include financial services and certain property transactions.

Supplies. VAT legislation does not exhaustively define the term supply but it is very broad in its scope. The distinction as to whether a supply is one of goods or services is important as different rules apply to the time and place of supply. Also the treatment of the international supply of goods and services is different.
VAT is charged at the value of a supply. The consideration agreed on is always inclusive of VAT unless the contrary is specified.

There are a number of transactions that are treated as neither a supply of goods nor of services and are therefore outside the scope of VAT. These include the transfer of a business as a going concern, services of employees, most supplies between members of a VAT group, dividends and transactions between divisions of the same corporate body.

Group registration. Two or more companies can be registered as a group for VAT purposes if one controls the others or some person controls all of them and each company either is resident in the UK for VAT purposes or has an established place of business in the UK. The representative group member is responsible for completing the VAT returns of the whole group and is principally liable for the whole group’s VAT. One of the main advantages of group registration is that transactions between members of a group are ignored for VAT purposes.

section1.para: Value added tax (VAT), alone among UK taxes, is an EU tax. It is levied by HM Customs & Excise on supplies for a consideration made by a "taxable person" in the UK in the course or furtherance of a business.

The broad framework of VAT is contained in a series of EC Directives, the principal one of which is the EC Sixth Directive (77/388/EEC). The primary UK legislation on VAT is the Value Added Tax Act 1994 (VATA 1994). This provides the framework of the tax but much of the detail is found in statutory instruments, either in the form of orders made by the Treasury or regulations made by Customs & Excise. Where UK legislation is clearly in conflict with EC law, EC law prevails.

section2.title: Taxable person
section2.para: A "taxable person" is an individual, limited company or other entity which is registered, or required to be registered, for VAT with Customs & Excise. The threshold for compulsory registration is an historical annual turnover of £50,000. A person must also register if he expects his turnover in the next 30 days to exceed £50,000. However, a tax payer can choose to register if he has a taxable turnover below £50,000. This is known as voluntary registration.

section2.title: Input and output tax
section2.para:
The essence of VAT is that it should be borne economically by the ultimate consumer of the goods or services supplied. Traders may generally deduct an amount equal to the VAT on supplies to them (
input tax
) from the VAT which they charge on supplies (
output tax
), and only pay the difference to Customs & Excise. Thus at each stage of the
supply chain
the net VAT paid is on the value added at that stage.

Although the tax is borne ultimately by the consumer, it is the supplier that has to pay the VAT chargeable on the supply to Customs & Excise as VAT is a liability of the person making the supply (section 1(2), VATA 1994). The supplier normally passes that liability on to his customer by identifying the price that he would have charged for his supply in the absence of VAT and increasing that price by an amount equal to the VAT that is in fact chargeable on the supply. A supplier's liability to pay VAT is thus simply another expense that a supplier should take into account when charging for goods. The only difference from other expenses is that, by convention, the additional amount paid by the recipient of the supply in respect of VAT is separately delineated.

VAT is therefore not a charge on the consumer as such, nor is the consumer "paying VAT"; he is paying additional consideration for the supply equal to the VAT liability of the supplier. This is fundamental to understanding how VAT works.

VAT clauses in documents that refer to consideration being "exclusive of VAT" are therefore misconceived. What they should say is that the consideration is "exclusive of any amount arising in respect of VAT" on the supply in question and that the purchaser "will pay a sum equal to such amount to the vendor by way of additional consideration".

section2.title: Calculation and rates
section2.para: Supplies are divided into three main categories for VAT purposes:

listitem.para: Standard rated supplies.
Zero rated supplies.
Exempt supplies.

section2.para: A reduced rate of 5% applies to supplies of fuel and power for domestic and certain other qualifying uses.

Standard rated supplies. Most supplies are subject to VAT at the standard rate of 17.5%. In its simplest form (where each person in the supply chain apart from the ultimate consumer is fully taxable at the standard rate), the tax operates so as to cause each person in the supply chain (other than the end user) to account to Customs & Excise for VAT on the value which that person adds to the goods or services in the chain, whilst the end user bears the cost of all the VAT previously accounted for.

The machinery devised to achieve this end is that each person in the supply chain pays to its suppliers input tax which is equal to the VAT on the gross value of the supplies it receives and accounts to Customs & Excise for the output tax on the gross value of the supplies it makes. The input tax is wholly credited against the output tax, leaving the person with an overall liability to VAT which is equal to 17.5% of the value added by that person.

For example, suppose that A supplies parts to B and B uses those parts to make machinery which it then sells to C. Suppose that the parts are sold to B for £100 plus an amount in respect of VAT of £17.50 and that B then sells the machinery to C for £200 plus an amount in respect of VAT of £35. A will account to Customs & Excise for output tax of £17.50 in respect of its supply to B. B will account for output tax of £35 in respect of its supply to C but will reclaim input tax of £17.50 from Customs & Excise. The net liability of B in respect of this transaction is therefore £17.50. If C is not registered for VAT, it will have paid £235 to B for the machinery, which includes £35 of irrecoverable input tax. This £35 was accounted for to Customs & Excise as to £17.50 by B and £17.50 by A (see inset box "A standard rated supply").

Zero rated supplies. Zero rated supplies do not require the supplier to charge VAT. They comprise a number of socially beneficial items, such as new houses, children's clothing, books, periodicals and newspapers ( Schedule 8, VATA 1994).

However, unlike an exempt supply, a zero rated supply is a taxable supply. It merely happens to be chargeable at a zero rate. A maker of zero rated supplies is able to recover all of the input tax which is attributable to his zero rated supplies (because such supplies are taxable) but is not required to account for output tax on those supplies (because of the zero rate). Thus, in economic terms, a zero rated supply breaks the accumulation of tax on added value which generally builds up in the supply chain.

For example, suppose that A supplies machinery to B, a clothes supplier, for £100 plus £17.50 in respect of VAT. B uses the machinery to manufacture children's clothes which it wishes to sell to C at a price which covers the cost of the machinery plus £100. The supply of children's clothes is zero rated for VAT purposes. Accordingly, B will be able to recover the £17.50 of input tax incurred on the acquisition of the machinery but will not be obliged to account for any output tax in respect of the supply of the children's clothes to C. The effect of this is that, in setting its prices for C, B will take into account only £100 of machinery costs as B will have recovered an amount equal to the aggregate of the VAT accounted for by A. C will therefore only be charged £200 for the clothes ( see inset box "A zero rated supply").

Exempt supplies. Where a person makes exempt supplies, he is treated in that respect as if he were the ultimate consumer . He is not required to account for output tax on his exempt supplies but he is unable to recover the input tax on those supplies which he has received that are attributable to his exempt supplies. In economic terms, this results in the ultimate consumer bearing the cost of value added by the standard rated suppliers earlier in the supply chain but not the cost of value added by the person making the exempt supply. Exempt supplies include financial services (for example, the sale of securities, lending money, underwriting, broking and insurance) and certain transactions in land and buildings (Schedule 9, VATA 1994).

For example, suppose that A supplies machinery to B, a bank, for £100 plus £17.50 in respect of VAT. B uses the machinery for the purposes of financial services supplied to C for which he wishes to recover the cost of the machinery plus £100. As the supply of financial services is an exempt supply, B will not be obliged to account for output tax in respect of supplies made to C. As, however, the machinery is being used for the purposes of making exempt supplies, B is not able to recover the input tax of £17.50 incurred on the acquisition of the machinery, and so the price charged by B to C will have to take into account this additional cost to B. C will therefore be charged £217.50 (see inset box "An exempt supply"). Failure by B to take into account this additional VAT cost will reduce B's profits in the same way that failure to take into account any other business expense would do so.

If B is not making wholly exempt supplies, but rather is using the machinery to make both standard rated and exempt supplies, B will be able to recover a proportion of the input tax incurred on the acquisition of the machinery and so the cost taken into account by B as part of its overheads will be reduced.

section2.title: Supply of goods and services
section2.para: The VAT legislation does not exhaustively define the term "supply" but it is very broad in its scope. It is defined to include circumstances in which, for example, a taxable person takes goods out of a business for private use, borrows goods for private use or puts his services to private use. Therefore, where a solicitor who is a taxable person does his own house conveyancing and uses his office staff and facilities for this purpose, he must account for VAT on the cost.

The distinction as to whether a supply is one of goods or services is important as different rules apply to the time and place of supply. Also the treatment of the international supply of goods and services is different (see "Place of supply" and "Time of supply" below).

"Goods" include capital assets and stock in trade. A "service" for this purpose is not only the provision of advice or skills to someone but also any other thing that is not a supply of goods but is done for consideration (such as the making of a loan, the sale or issue of a share or the waiver of a legal right) (section 5(2), VATA 1994). A transaction in land may be either a supply of goods or services, depending on the nature of the interest in land that is the subject of the transaction.

section2.title: Place of supply
section2.para: To be within the charge to UK VAT, a supply must be made in the UK. Supplies made outside the UK are outside the scope of UK VAT (although they may be liable to VAT in another country). It is therefore important to establish where a particular supply is made. Separate rules apply to the supply of goods and services:
Goods. If goods are outside the UK, the supply is treated as made outside the UK. If goods are inside the UK, the supply is treated as made in the UK.

If the supply involves the removal of goods from the UK they are treated as supplied in the UK. If the supply involves the removal of goods to the UK they are to be treated as supplied outside the UK.

Therefore, exports are supplies of goods which are within the scope of VAT, whereas imports are supplies which are outside the scope of VAT, at least in relation to the charge to VAT on taxable supplies. The importer is however likely to be liable to account for VAT on the supply (see below).

Thus, the whole issue turns solely on the physical location of the goods themselves. It does not matter where either party to the supply has its main business presence. For example, if the goods that form the subject matter of the supply are held somewhere in the UK, the place of supply is in the UK even if neither the maker of the supply nor the recipient have any form of business establishment or other business presence in the UK.

Services. The basic rule is that a supply of services is treated as made in the country where the supplier himself "belongs" for VAT purposes (see inset box "Meaning of "belongs""). There are however a number of important exceptions to this basic rule ( VAT (Place of Supply of Services) Order 1992 SI 3121) (the Order). The main exceptions are:

listitem.para: Where a supply of services relates to land, it is treated as made in the country where the land in connection with which the supply is made is itself situated; it does not matter where either party to the supply "belongs".

Where a supply of services consists of any services set out in Article 15 of the Order (which include, for example, conferences, sporting and entertainment services), it is treated as made in the country where the services themselves are physically carried out; it does not matter where either party to the supply belongs (see inset box "Article 15 services").

Where a person belonging in the UK makes a supply of any services falling within paragraphs (i)-(viii) of Schedule 5 of the VATA 1994 (which include legal, banking and financial services) to a person who belongs outside the UK and in a country (other than the Isle of Man) that is not an EU member state, the supply is treated as made in the country where the recipient "belongs" and is accordingly outside the scope of UK VAT (see inset box "Schedule 5 services").

Where a person belonging in the UK makes a supply of any Schedule 5 services to a person who "belongs" outside the UK but in a country that is another EU member state, the supply is treated as made in the member state where the recipient belongs, and is accordingly outside the scope of UK VAT if, and only if:
the recipient receives the supply for the purpose of a business carried on by him; and
the recipient is registered for the local equivalent of VAT in the member state in which he belongs.

section2.title: Time of supply
section2.para: The time at which a supply of goods or services takes place is called the tax point. It is a significant date. A supplier becomes liable to VAT by reference to the time of supply. The timing of credit for input tax is also referable to the time of supply.
There are different rules for goods and services all of which can be displaced by prior issue of a VAT invoice or payment.
Goods. There are three basic rules relating to goods:

listitem.para: If the goods are to be removed, the tax point is the time of removal (that is, the date when they are sent to the customer or he takes them away).

If the goods are not to be removed (for example, because they are built on site) the tax point is when they are made available to the recipient. For example, on a sale of the freehold in a building, the freehold is normally "made available" on legal completion.

If the goods are removed, but at the time of removal it is unclear whether a supply will actually take place (because they are on approval or subject to sale or return), the supply is treated as taking place when it becomes clear that a supply has taken place or, if sooner, twelve months after the removal.

section2.para: Services. Services are treated as taking place at the time they are performed. This seems to mean at the time when they are completed (subject to some special provisions relating to continuous supplies, such as construction work or the leasing of land or goods, where the consideration is payable periodically).
Exceptions. The above rules relating to goods and services can be displaced by one of two events occurring before the date which would otherwise be the tax point:

listitem.para: VAT invoice. The issue of a VAT invoice for a standard rated supply. Where this occurs, the supply is treated as taking place at the time of the tax invoice.
Payment. If a payment is received in respect of a supply of any type, the supply is to be treated as taking place when payment is received.
In both of the above cases, the supply is treated as taking place only to the extent of the amount invoiced or payment received.

If a VAT invoice is issued within 14 days after the time when a standard rated supply would otherwise be treated as taking place, the date of the VAT invoice is substituted for the date which would otherwise have been the tax point.

section2.title: Value of supply
section2.para: VAT is charged on the value of a supply. Where the only consideration for a supply is money, the value of the supply is the amount which, once the tax charged on the supply is added to it, equals the consideration for the supply (section 19(2), VATA 1994).

The consideration agreed on is therefore inclusive of VAT unless the contrary is so specified. This is a fundamental point. If a supplier wants a customer to pay him an amount that will cover the supplier's liability to VAT on the supply, he must ensure that the contract specifically requires that amount to be paid.

Where the consideration for a supply does not consist wholly of money, the value of the supply is taken as such amount of money as, with the addition of VAT chargeable, is equivalent to that consideration (section 19(3), VATA 1994). There are special rules relating to discounts, transactions between connected persons and values expressed in foreign currencies.

section2.title: Supplies outside the scope of VAT
section2.para: There are a number of transactions that are treated as neither a supply of goods nor of services and are therefore outside the scope of VAT. These include:

listitem.para: The transfer of a business as a going concern. This applies to the sale of the whole of a business or of part of a business that is capable of separate operation (Article 5, Value Added Tax (Special Provisions) Order 1995, SI 1995/1268).
Most supplies between members of a VAT group (see "Group registration" below).
Services of employees. (The services of a self-employed person are within the scope of VAT.)
Dividends.
Transactions between divisions of the same corporate body.

Financial, legal or accountancy advice given to a client that is supplied either to a client belonging in, and registered for VAT in, another EU member state who receives the advice for business purposes or to a client who belongs outside the EU (Schedule 5, VATA 1994).

Services provided by an agent acting in his own name to a purchaser of goods where the consideration for the services is taken into account in calculating the price at which the agent obtained the goods (Article 9, Value Added Tax (Special Provisions) Order 1995, SI 1995/1268).

section2.para: Where services are outside the scope of VAT, sometimes the supplier can obtain a refund of related input tax (see inset box "Corporate transactions").

section2.title: Imports and exports
section2.para: Different rules apply for goods and services which are imported to or exported from the UK.

Goods. Goods imported from a country outside the EU are subject to VAT if the same goods supplied in the UK by a registered trader would be subject to VAT. The rate is the same as would apply to a UK supply.

An importer of goods from outside the EU must calculate and pay VAT on the value of goods imported (the price plus packaging, freight as far as the first destination in the EU, insurance, commission and customs and excise duties). This will be treated as input tax in his hands. Exports of goods outside the EU are generally zero rated.
Services. If standard rated services are supplied to a person belonging in the UK by a trader that belongs outside the UK (inside or outside the EU), VAT may be charged in one of two ways:

listitem.para: Under the reverse charge system, certain supplies (including those in paragraphs (i)-(viii) of Schedule 5 of the VATA 1994 (see inset box " Schedule 5 services")) are treated as made by the UK recipient who must therefore pay VAT on their value. This will be treated as input tax in his hands. Correspondingly, some services supplied by UK traders to overseas customers are not subject to UK VAT because they will be treated as supplied in the country of the recipient.
VAT may have to be charged by the supplier in the ordinary way if he is registered.

section2.title: Goods sold within the EU
section2.para: The general approach for goods sold within the EU is:

listitem.para: If the goods are sold between traders that are VAT registered, the supplier shows the customer's state code and VAT registration number on the invoice and zero rates the supply. The customer must pay VAT at his country's rate on the supply to him.
On a supply to an unregistered customer, the supplier applies VAT (at his own country's rate) in the same way that he would for a sale in his own country.
If a supplier makes substantial sales to unregistered buyers in one country, for example, by mail order, he may have to register in that country and apply its VAT rate.

section2.para: There are exceptions to these rules affecting particular goods including motor vehicles, ships and aircraft.

section2.title: Group registration
section2.para: Two or more companies can be registered as a group for VAT purposes if one controls the others or some person (not necessarily a company itself) controls all of them and each company either is resident in the UK for VAT purposes or has an established place of business in the UK.
The test of control is that which applies in section 736 of the Companies Act 1985 so that one company is a subsidiary of another, if the other company:

listitem.para: Holds a majority of the voting rights in it; or
Is a member of it and has the right to appoint or remove a majority of its board of directors; or
Is a member of it and controls alone, pursuant to an agreement with other shareholders or members, a majority of the voting rights in it.

A group has to be registered as a group and only extends to companies that have been registered as members of it. When a group is in existence, one member, called the representative member, is responsible for completing the VAT returns of the whole group and is principally liable for the whole group's VAT. The main consequences of group registration are:
Transactions between members of a group are completely ignored for VAT purposes, regardless of whether they would otherwise have been taxable or exempt supplies.
All supplies made to or by any member of a VAT group are treated as made to or by the representative member alone.

All members are jointly and severally liable for any VAT due from the representative member. In other words, each member of the group is contingently liable to pay the tax chargeable on the supplies made by the whole group, and not merely on what would have been its own supplies had it been separately registered.

section2.para: Customs & Excise issued a consultative document in June 1998 containing a proposal that companies that are exempt or partially exempt (that is, cannot recover all VAT charged to them) should not be eligible for inclusion in a VAT group. In general, this is an unwelcome proposal for exempt or partially exempt businesses, particularly those businesses that will receive taxable supplies from associated companies if excluded from the VAT group.

section2.title: VAT returns
section2.para: Once a person is registered, it must account for VAT on the output of goods or services. It can credit any input tax on goods or services wholly used by him in making taxable supplies (that is, non-exempt supplies). The business is allocated a VAT number and must make returns to Customs & Excise. Generally this is done every three months.

section1.title: Article 15 services
section1.para: Where a supply of services consists of any services set out in Article 15 of the VAT (Place of Supply of Services) Order 1992, it is treated as made in the country where the services themselves are physically carried out; it does not matter where either party to the supply belongs. Services specified in Article 15 of the Order are:

listitem.para: Cultural, artistic, sporting, scientific, educational or entertainment services.
Services relating to exhibitions, conferences or meetings.
Services ancillary to, including those of organising, any supply of a description within the above two paragraphs.
The valuation of, or work carried out on, any goods.

section1.title: Meaning of "belongs"
section1.para: A supplier or recipient "belongs" in a particular country if he has a business establishment or some fixed establishment in that country and no such establishment in any other country.
If the supplier or recipient has no business establishment or other fixed establishment in any country, he belongs in the country where he has his usual place of residence.
The supplier of services is to be treated as belonging in the country in which is situated his establishment which is "most directly concerned with the supply".

The recipient of services is to be treated as belonging in the country in which is situated his establishment "at which, or for the purposes of which, the services are most directly used or to be used".

section1.title: Schedule 5 services
section1.para: Services falling within paragraphs (i)-(viii), Schedule 5, VATA 1994 are:

listitem.para: (i) Transfers and assignments of copyright, patents, licences, trademarks and similar rights.
(ii) Advertising services.

(iii) Services of consultants, engineers, consultancy bureaux, lawyers, accountants and other similar services; data processing and provision of information (but excluding from any services relating to land).
(iv) Acceptance of any obligation to refrain from pursuing or exercising, in whole or part, any business activity or any rights as referred to in paragraph (i) above.
(v) Banking, financial and insurance services (including reinsurance, but not including the provision of safe deposit facilities).
(vi) The supply of staff.
(vii) The letting on hire of goods other than means of transport.
(viii) The services rendered by one person to another in procuring for the other any of the services mentioned in paragraphs (i) to (vii) above.

section1.title: Corporate transactions
section1.para: Corporate transactions are likely to involve a variety of advisers and different types of advice for VAT purposes. The following is a general guide.

section2.title: UK supplies
section2.para: The "making of arrangements" for the issue, transfer, receipt of, or any dealing with securities is exempt if made in the UK. The exemption only applies to the party (or parties) that co-ordinates all the components of the transaction and concludes it, for example, an investment or merchant bank. Arranging issues of securities includes offers for sale, rights issues, vendor placings, cash offers and bids with underwritten cash alternatives. Underwriting services provided to a UK issuer are also exempt.

Other parties providing specialist services (for example, reporting accountants and legal advisers) are not generally regarded as "making arrangements" and their services are therefore standard rated.
The services of preparing and issuing advice to investors to reject or accept a takeover bid or offer to purchase shares are also taxable at the standard rate when supplied in the UK.
The supply of general financial or investment advice to a UK client is standard rated.

section2.title: Non-UK supplies
section2.para: The "making of arrangements" for the issue, transfer, receipt of, or any dealing with securities and underwriting services are:

listitem.para: Outside the scope of VAT with no input tax credit if the advice is supplied to a client belonging and registered for VAT in another EU member state, who receives the supply for business purposes.
Exempt for a private EC client.
Outside the scope of UK VAT with input tax credit for a non-EC client.

section2.para: General legal, accountancy and financial advice is outside the scope of UK VAT but with input tax credit if supplied either to a client belonging in, and registered for VAT in, another EU member state who receives the advice for business purposes or to a client outside the EU.

section1.title: Glossary
section1.para:
Input tax.
Input tax is VAT paid by a taxable person on the supply of taxable goods or services received by him for the purposes of his business. This may be offset against any output tax charged by him on the onward taxable supply of those goods or services. The difference is payable to Customs & Excise. It is also known as input VAT.

Output tax.
Output tax is VAT charged by a taxable person when supplying taxable goods or services for the purposes of his business. It is also known as output VAT.

Supply chain.
VAT is a cumulative tax on consumption charged at each stage in the chain of the supply of goods or services. The supply chain refers to the way in which VAT is charged at each stage by each supplier who offsets it against his input tax. The VAT charge is borne by the final consumer at the end of the supply chain.
